title: PSM 1 Certification Flashcards - Batch 3 (Cards 21-50)
description: Comprehensive Scrum Framework Flashcards covering Roles, Events, Artifacts, and Exam Tips

cards.front: Who is accountable for maximizing product value?
cards.back: The Product Owner.

cards.front: Who ensures Scrum is understood and enacted?
cards.back: The Scrum Master.

cards.front: Who is responsible for turning Product Backlog items into Increments?
cards.back: The Developers.

cards.front: Can the Scrum Master assign tasks to Developers?
cards.back: No, Developers are self-managing.

cards.front: Who decides what work will be done in the Sprint?
cards.back: Developers select items from the Product Backlog during Sprint Planning.

cards.front: Can the Product Owner change the Sprint Backlog?
cards.back: No, only Developers can change it.

cards.front: Who creates the Definition of Done?
cards.back: The Scrum Team.

cards.front: What is the role of stakeholders in Scrum?
cards.back: Provide feedback and collaborate during the Sprint Review.

cards.front: Can one person be both Product Owner and Scrum Master?
cards.back: It's not recommended; these are separate accountabilities.

cards.front: Who ensures the Product Backlog is visible and transparent?
cards.back: The Product Owner.

cards.front: What are the three Scrum Artifacts?
cards.back: Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, and Increment.

cards.front: What is the commitment associated with the Product Backlog?
cards.back: The Product Goal.

cards.front: What is the commitment for the Sprint Backlog?
cards.back: The Sprint Goal.

cards.front: What is the commitment for the Increment?
cards.back: The Definition of Done.

cards.front: What is the Definition of Done?
cards.back: A shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete.

cards.front: Can the Product Backlog be changed after Sprint Planning?
cards.back: Yes, it's a living artifact that evolves.

cards.front: What does the Sprint Backlog contain?
cards.back: Selected Product Backlog items, the Sprint Goal, and a plan for delivery.

cards.front: Who manages the Sprint Backlog?
cards.back: The Developers.

cards.front: What is a Product Goal?
cards.back: The long-term objective for the Scrum Team.

cards.front: How often is the Product Backlog refined?
cards.back: Continuously, as needed.

cards.front: Is Scrum a methodology?
cards.back: No, it's a framework.

cards.front: What kind of process control does Scrum use?
cards.back: Empirical process control.

cards.front: What happens if work doesn't meet the Definition of Done?
cards.back: It cannot be released or counted as part of the Increment.

cards.front: What's the primary measure of progress in Scrum?
cards.back: Working, usable software.

cards.front: Should the Scrum Master remove all impediments?
cards.back: The Scrum Master helps the team remove them, but does not do all the work.

cards.front: What happens if the Product Owner is unavailable?
cards.back: The Scrum Team may be blocked; it's crucial to have a dedicated and available PO.

cards.front: Can new work be added to a Sprint once it starts?
cards.back: Only if Developers agree and it doesn't compromise the Sprint Goal.

cards.front: What if the team can't complete all Sprint Backlog items?
cards.back: The incomplete items return to the Product Backlog for future consideration.

cards.front: Should the Scrum Master attend the Daily Scrum?
cards.back: They can, but it's primarily for the Developers.

cards.front: Is velocity a required metric in Scrum?
cards.back: No, Scrum doesn't prescribe velocity; teams may choose to track it.
